title: World Regions
text: This page depicts trends within world regions. The first graph shows us the world regions that will be used in the subsequent graphs. The second graph shows the amount of money different world regions spend on education. The third graph shows the urban population within world regions from 2010 to 2020. The last graph does the same but with rural populations.

title: What are the effects of education expenditure on Urban and Rural Populations?
text: How does the effects of national government expenditure on education differ from the urban population to the rural population? The data to answer the question was sourced from the World Bank Universal Indicator dataset, and then the relevant data frames were combined to analyze the relationships between government expenditure on urban populations vs. rural populations. The graphs below show that there is very little connection between urban and rural population growths and how much a country’s government spends on its education department. The linear regression models in the models tab depict that as well.

title: What are the effects of education expenditure on Urban and Rural Populations?
text: How does the effects of national government expenditure on education differ from the urban population to the rural population? The data to answer the question was sourced from the World Bank Universal Indicator dataset, and then the relevant data frames were combined to analyze the relationships between government expenditure on urban populations vs. rural populations. The graphs below show that there is very little connection between urban and rural population growths and how much a country’s government spends on its education department. The linear regression models in the models tab depict that as well.

title: Development Factors
text: How does government spending on education affect the development of urban and rural areas? On this page we have 3 sets of graphs analyzing the potential effects of a government’s education expenditure on 3 developmental factors: Access to Electricity, Safe Drinking Water and Basic Sanitation Services.

title: About Me
text:
My Name is Luit Deka and I am a senior at Liberty High School, Frisco TX USA. You can reach me at luitdeka@gmail.com.
Here is My Github
I was fortunate to learn about data science in Kane’s Free Data Science Bootcamp led by Preceptor David Kane PhD. I recommend this course to anyone interested in Data Science.

title: Conclusion
text: As we saw in the Home and model pages, increased expenditure on education does not have a substantial impact upon urban and rural population growths. Despite this, increased spending on education still benefits both rural and urban populations in terms of quality of life and access to resources. However, it is important to keep in mind that these relationships are mainly correlative as there are many other factors that we must consider before we determine these associations to be causal.

title: Model Analysis
text: How does a government’s expenditure on education impact rural and urban population growths?

title: Model Analysis
text:
Model Definitions
\[y_u = \beta_0  + \beta_1 x_{1,u} + \epsilon_u\]
with \(y_u = Urban\_PopGrowth\), \(x_1 = edu\_exp\), and \(\epsilon_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\).
\[y_r = \beta_0  + \beta_1 x_{1,r} + \epsilon_r\] with \(y_u = Rural\_PopGrowth\), \(x_1 = edu\_exp\), and \(\epsilon_r \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\).


stan_glm
 family:       gaussian [identity]
 formula:      Edu_Exp ~ Urban_PopGrowth
 observations: 1447
 predictors:   2
------
                Median         MAD_SD        
(Intercept)     448291202312.4  51608403832.4
Urban_PopGrowth -58004683565.4  19200689288.4

Auxiliary parameter(s):
      Median       MAD_SD      
sigma 1.189343e+12 2.232049e+10

------
* For help interpreting the printed output see ?print.stanreg
* For info on the priors used see ?prior_summary.stanreg

title: Sources
